factoid: The enemy was on the high ground.
Smoke of a cannon rose on the high ground.
A cannonball flew whistling over the heads of the hussar squadron.
The officers who had been standing together rode off to their places.
The hussars began carefully aligning their horses.
Silence fell on the whole squadron.
All hussars were looking at the enemy in front.
All hussars were looking at the squadron commander.
All hussars were awaiting the word of command.
A second cannonball flew past.
A third cannonball flew past.
The enemy fired at the hussars.
The cannonballs flew over the heads of the horsemen.
The cannonballs fell somewhere beyond the horsemen.
The hussars did not look round.
The hussars looked at the sound of each shot.
The hussars looked at the word of command.
The whole squadron held its breath while the cannonball flew past.
The whole squadron rose in the stirrups while the cannonball flew past.
The whole squadron sank back again after the cannonball flew past.
The soldiers without turning their heads glanced at one another.
The soldiers were curious to see their comrades’ impression.
Every face from Denísov’s to the bugler’s showed a common expression of conflict, irritation, and excitement.
The expression was around the chin and mouth.
The quartermaster frowned.
The quartermaster looked at the soldiers as if threatening to punish them.
Cadet Mirónov ducked every time a cannonball flew past.
Rostóv was on the left flank.
Rostóv was mounted on his horse Rook.
Rook was a handsome horse despite its game leg.
Rostóv had the happy air of a schoolboy called up before a large audience for an examination.
Rostóv felt sure he would distinguish himself in the examination.
Rostóv was glancing at everyone with a clear, bright expression.
Rostóv was asking everyone to notice how calmly he sat under fire.
Rostóv’s face showed an indication of something new and stern around the mouth.
Denísov cried 'Who’s that curtseying there?'.
Denísov cried 'Cadet Miwónov!'.
Denísov cried 'That’s not wight!'.
Denísov cried 'Look at me.'.
Denísov was unable to keep still on one spot.
Denísov kept turning his horse in front of the squadron.
Váska Denísov had a black, hairy, snub-nosed face.
Váska Denísov had a short sturdy figure.
Váska Denísov had a sinewy hairy hand.
Váska Denísov had stumpy fingers.
Váska Denísov held the hilt of his naked saber.
Váska Denísov looked just as it usually did, especially toward evening when he had emptied his second bottle.
Váska Denísov was only redder than usual.
Váska Denísov had a shaggy head thrown back like birds when they drink.
Váska Denísov pressed his spurs mercilessly into the sides of his horse Bedouin.
Váska Denísov was sitting as though falling backwards in the saddle.
Váska Denísov galloped to the other flank of the squadron.
Váska Denísov shouted in a hoarse voice to the men to look to their pistols.
Váska Denísov rode up to Kírsten.
The staff captain rode on a broad-backed, steady mare.
The staff captain came at a walk to meet Váska Denísov.
The staff captain had a long mustache.
The staff captain’s face was serious as always.
The staff captain’s eyes were brighter than usual.
The staff captain said 'Well, what about it?' to Denísov.
The staff captain said 'It won’t come to a fight.'.
The staff captain said 'You’ll see—we shall retire.'.
Denísov muttered 'The devil only knows what they’re about!'.
Denísov cried 'Ah, Wostóv,' noticing the cadet’s bright face.
Denísov said 'you’ve got it at last.'.
The staff captain smiled approvingly, evidently pleased with the cadet.
Rostóv felt perfectly happy.
The commander appeared on the bridge.
Denísov galloped up to the commander.
Denísov said 'Your excellency! Let us attack them! I’ll dwive them off.'.
The colonel said 'Attack indeed!'.
The colonel spoke in a bored voice.
The colonel puckered up his face as if driving off a troublesome fly.
The colonel asked 'And why are you stopping here?'.
The colonel asked 'Don’t you see the skirmishers are retreating?'.
The colonel commanded 'Lead the squadron back.'.
The squadron crossed the bridge.
The squadron drew out of range of fire.
The squadron did not lose a single man.
The second squadron that had been in the front line followed the first squadron across.
The last Cossacks quitted the farther side of the river.
